The whill the host was thus in Ossory, befel þat þay were&ntail; a n&ydot;ght I-loget in an ol&dtail; caste&llbar;, & aboute; an&dtail; these twe&ydot;n, as ha&rtail; wone was, weren botℏ I-hosted to-gedderes: ffe&rtail; with-yn nyght come an host vp-on ham, of so mycℏ folk as thegℏ hit were fele thousan&dtail;, on euer&ydot; side sm&ydot;tynge vp the host as they wolden in wode raas ferly ouersai&llbar; hame, al, with wepne r&ydot;ng&ydot;nge, speres an&dtail; sparthes ruthlynge to-geddre, with cryynge so grysl&ydot; that noon ende was of helf fa&rtail;, as hoft -sithes was wonet to be-fa&llbar; in ostynges in Irlan&dtail;; of whicℏe frightnes the most parte of the oste was so afer&dtail;, that þay flowe and hidden ha&mtail;, some in wodnes, som in mores.  These twey stalwar&dtail; mē&nmacr; henten ha&rtail; wepene, & lep to hors, and wenten a-noon to Robertes tentes, (Steuenes sone,) an&dtail; cryed vp-on ha&rtail; felowes þat day sholden withston&dtail;, an&dtail; tak hert to hame, an&dtail; defen&dtail; ham-self; bot few the&rtail; we&rtail; that so diden, til they saw that this crie an&dtail; þe noise was all I-left, & nas bot fantasy.  Whan the host hem gaddred aya&ydot;n to-geddre, tha&ydot; we&rtail; fu&llbar; so&rtail; ashamet that thay so argl&ydot; put ham to f l ight, an&dtail; mycℏ speche was amonge ham, an&dtail; man&ydot;, hadden gret enu&ydot;, an&dtail; m&ydot;ch wonder toght of Robert de bar&rtail;, that whan the host was in so gret frightnes, he was that ma&ntail; þat stydfastl&ydot; most h&ydot;m held, an&dtail; most h&ydot;m entised for to witℏston&dtail; an&dtail; fight; an&dtail; amonge a&llbar; the goode thewes that in hym weren, þis inamliche is i-tol&dtail; of h&ydot;m, that for no violence ne ferl&ydot; aduentu&rtail; þat hym m&ydot;ght betid, he was neuer whan-hopefully argh, ne afer&dtail;, ne amaye&dtail; of hert, ne shamefully ne didde hym to flight, bot euer mo&rtail; he was I-licℏ redy to weppen an&dtail; to defen&dtail; hym-self, an&dtail; to helpen all oþer; he the formost kn&ydot;ght that in this conqueste of Irlan&dtail; first receyue&dtail; d&ydot;nt an&dtail; hurt&ydot;ng in battaill.  A wonde&rtail; was of that fantasye: A-morowe wha&ntail; hit was da&ydot;, I the place, ther this folk I-se&ydot;e sm&ydot;ten vp-on hame, the wedes an&dtail; the grase 
 that stoden al euen vp-right, thay lay a&llbar; I-drow a-doune and I-cast to gron&dtail;. This grass, &c. only in Harl. MS . 177. Op . v. 236.

5.1:
As this was on this maner I-do&ntail;, the tyth&ydot;nges sprongen in-to al Irlan&dtail; hwow Macmorgℏ conquered his lon&dtail; vpon his men, an&dtail; that no man myght hym withston&dtail; for out-comen men that he lade with hym.  Roryk O'Concow&rtail; of Connaght, that was that t&ydot;m kynge of al Irlan&dtail;, vndrestod h&ydot;m, an&dtail; toght in his hert the gret peril that myght be-fa&llbar; h&ydot;m an&dtail; al the lon&dtail; folk, drogℏ the owt-comen folk þat was thus in-to the lan&dtail; I-co&mtail;; he sent his messagers to al the gret me&ntail; of the lon&dtail;, an&dtail; in a lityll whi&llbar; gaddred ham to-geddre to a parlement, an&dtail; tok ham to rede that euery on his half shol&dtail; gaddre al the powe&rtail; þat they myght, for to we&rtail; vpon Macmorgℏ.  And as hit was purueied, so hit was do&ntail;; Thay assemblet so many hostes an&dtail; so m&ydot;ch folk on euery half, that noon en&dtail; was, an&dtail; come&ntail; to Okensel&ydot; for to weren vpon Macmorgℏ.  Whan this hostes weren thus assemblet, the most parte of Macmorghis me&ntail;, ayeyne ha&rtail; trowth an&dtail; aye&ydot;n ha&rtail; othes, some priuely whithdrow hem that da&ydot;, nold nat to hym com, some al openly leften h&ydot;m, and wenten to his fomen ayey&ntail; hy&mtail;; so that, in his most nede, trew frendes ne fonde he no&ntail;, sawe Robert, steuenes so&ntail;, and his. With the lit&ydot;ll folk that tha&ydot; hadden, thay wenten in-to a place nat fe&rtail; frome ffernes, a ple&ydot;n place bisette about with montaignes and woddes, watres and mores, on euery side il to co&mtail; to .  the entrees that ther were&ntail;, by Robert-is deuice thay setten me&ntail; for to stopen, in some place with trees I-cast do&ntail;, an&dtail; in other places depe diches I-cast.  thegℏ the place we&rtail; stronge of kynde, thay made&ntail; hit mycℏ stronge r with engyn, so that hit was I-now seke&rtail; recet to ha&mtail;, an&dtail; to he&rtail; enem&ydot;es ful stron>ail; to co&mtail; to, and with litill folke hit myght be I-kept; & derne weies thay hadden purueie&dtail; to ha&mtail;-self, owt to goo, ayey&ntail; In to co&mtail;, whan ha&mtail; liked.  Whane the kynge of Connaght, with so many hostes, was to ha&mtail; I-co&mtail;, he send to Robert by Messangers, an&dtail; present h&ydot;m with rych yiftes, an&dtail; many mo he hym be-het, an&dtail; fast hy&mtail; be-soght that, owt of þe Contray, wyche no Right
 he ne hadde to, &nmacr;e no chalange ne myght setten vp-on, he and his, witℏ pees and lou e shold departe.  Micℏ they spek of this, and litell thay sped.  The&rtail;-afty&rtail;, the messagers turned to Macmorgℏ, and be-soghten hy&mtail; on the kynges half, OConghou&rtail;, that he forth, with ha&mtail;, shold turne vp-o&ntail; the owt-come&ntail; folk, ha&mtail; to slee an&dtail; vndo.  And if he so wold, thay wold delyuer hym al leynest&rtail;, and stidfast pees and fren&dtail;-shippe mak hym haue of the kynge an&dtail; of all other.  Many reisons tha&ydot; shewed, both for the land & for the lan&dtail; folk; bot notynge thay ne spedde, ne noo&ntail; answa&rtail; ne hadden, that ham liket.  Oconghou&rtail; saw an&dtail; herd of his Messagers that he myght nat in sucℏ maner spede, an&dtail; that he most witℏ streyntℏ do, that he myght nat with fai&rtail; speche: he tok his wepne grymly, and sto&dtail; vp a-monge his folk, and thus sayd to ha&mtail;; "Mighty me&ntail;, and stalwar&dtail; in fight for to defende your lon&dtail; an&dtail; your franchise! vndrestondetℏ, ayey&ntail; whice folk, an&dtail; for what encheso&ntail;, ye sho&llbar; this battai&llbar; tak an hon&dtail;: al oure enemy, that afor thus was owt of lon&dtail; I-dryw for his wykkednesse, In commune confusio&ntail; of vs all, al be-tak with owt-comen & wepned folk, is ayay&ntail; commen for enuy and harme of vs, & hath I-broght vnke&dtail; folk vp-o&ntail; vs, that the harme wicℏ he ha&dtail; no powe&rtail; to do&ntail; vs h&ydot;m-self, throgℏ helpe of ha&mtail; & mayntenaunce, the better myght brynge to en&dtail;; an&dtail; hath dight hem to sheden his att&ydot;&rtail; so wide, that he rechet nat of his ow&ntail; deth, bot that al mowe&ntail; hawe ou&rtail; bale troghe h&ydot;&mtail;, an&dtail; for noo&ntail; shol&dtail; be I-spared, an&dtail; he ne spared h&ydot;m-self.  Ther-for we willen withston&dtail; the beg&ydot;n&ydot;nge, and þe yuel whil hit is com&ydot;n, ar hit be Iroted; ffor harme wexet euer with longe abidd&ydot;nge. Ou&rtail; lond & ou&rtail; fredo&mtail; defended we manly; so that the slaght of þese fewe be ferdnesse to many; & be ensample of these, al other out-lon&dtail; me&ntail; to be adrede, such folies to beg&ydot;n, an&dtail; the mynd of vs, with-out en&dtail; to rest ."

6.1:
Macmorgh, on his halue, be-held his me&ntail;, and saw ha&mtail; so&rtail; amayed: with wordes that he myght, he conforted ha&mtail; on this maner: "Men of leynester, which, sothfast trowth & stidfaste kynd in al aduentures, vs hath felawes I-make&dtail;, 
 without any partyng, a-re&rtail; we ou&rtail; hertes, styfly vs-self to defend. The maistre of wreth and of Coueytise, that with streynth wold vs brynge vnderfoot, and ows ayeyn dr&ydot;ue out of lond, othe&rtail;, that wors is, in the same lon&dtail;, vs tynken vndo: that god shil&dtail;! loo, he&rtail; is I-co&mtail; vpon ou&rtail; he&dtail;, of his m&ydot;cℏ gader&ydot;nge of folke prowt & haute&ydot;n. be ye well vndrestond, þat nat trogℏ gret tale of men ne trogh greth streynth, both drogℏ right and trowth that ma&ntail; hath with hym, battailles doth ouerco&mtail;.  We haue for vs, ayey&ntail; ha&rtail; pryd, mekenes; ayayns har vnr&ydot;ght, right an&dtail; trouth; ayeyn ha&rtail; boldenesse and ouer-truste, mekenesse and maner.  Thay fighten for coueytise, for to get good; an&dtail; we, for to flee harme. with al this we bene in stron>ail; place an&dtail; wel I-warne&dtail;.  The mo&rtail; that he&rtail; commeth, the more encombrement we shall do hame, by lityll folk ham to ouerco&mtail;, so that we be of on hert, and stifly withston&dtail;.'

7.1:
Whan Macmorghe ha&dtail; his tale I-endeth in his speche, Robert Steuenes-so&ntail;, spake to his felaws an&dtail; to his meigne on this wise: "ffightyn>ail; fors, & yongelynges I-corne, that so many perilles hawe to-geddre I-soffre&dtail;, an&dtail; euer in al aduentures, an&dtail; of heigh hert ibe! If we inly vndrestonde wiche me&ntail; we ben, with what lodes-ma&ntail;, an&dtail; for what th&ydot;nge we this perille vndre-tok with stalwardnesse, as ou&rtail; wone ys, we shullen ouercome; & the grace that ye I-haue i-hadde ar this of go&dtail;, ne shal vs nat forlete.  Of the folke of Troy we ben kyndl&ydot;ch y-come, o&ntail; þat oon half, fro þe first begynnyge; of ffraunce, we haue kynde on othe&rtail; half.  Throgh kyn&dtail; of Troy, we owe to be hardy; throgh kynd of ffraunce, we ben vsed in wepene; & so as we bene of double mane kyndl&ydot;, of good herth & we&llbar; y-wepne&dtail;, & well y-lernet yn wepne, ne dout no man, þat such vnwepne&dtail; rascay&llbar; any powe&rtail; haw ows to wythston&dtail;: o&ntail; that othe&rtail; halue, we come nat yn-to thys land as hyryn>ail; men, ne for no couetyse of gol&dtail;, ne of syluy&rtail;, ne galyot&yogh; ne robbers; bott for to helpe thys heyth man that ys so noble & so fre, &, þrogh hys owne men, lodderly was of lon&dtail; y-dryue. we hawe reuth of hys har&mtail;; & helpeth vp þat adoun was &ydot;-bro&yogh;the; to hys kyn&dtail; sted, bryngeth hym þat vnkyndly was
 the&rtail;-of I-bansheth.  And he, as largh ma&ntail; & goo&dtail; prynce, hat vs yeue&ntail; wyde londes & ryche townes, & ow&rtail; lond folke wyll setten & planten stydfastly yn þys lond, nowe & euer .  Therfor, men, full of streynth & stalwarthnes, such thyn>ail; y-mag&ydot;neth to-day hartly to do, that ow&rtail; kynred ne go nat out of kyn&dtail;, & yn th&ydot;s, lyuynge oþer dey, we manly wy&ntail; the pryce, that euer more torne to whyrshyppe vs & al ou&rtail; that afty&rtail; ws shullen come."

8.1: Wythe these wordes, & othe&rtail; suche, these heghe me&ntail; comforte&dtail; ha&rtail; folk, for day schulde&ntail; hawe the bettyr wyll well for to f&ydot;ght.  And wha&ntail; day were o&ntail; euery half redy for to smyth to-geddre, OCono&yogh;w&ydot;r, be-tho&yogh;ghth&ydot;ng that the aduentu&rtail; of battaylle ben ofte doutouse & m&ydot;che vncerteyne, And as the whysma&ntail; seythe 'all tynge me sha&llbar; assay, rathe&rtail; tha&ntail; fy&yogh;th,' & all-so he & hys doutende&ntail; well sore to assemble with folke I-wepne&dtail;, On al maner that he my&yogh;ght, He was abowte thame sholde make peas.  thane, throgℏ besechyn>ail; of goode men&etail; that went betwene, & throgℏ grace of the holy goste, was the peas y-made, o&ntail; þis maner; that thay sholde leve leynester to Maccmorghowe, & he sholde hitt holde of Oconoghou&rtail;, & hym knowlech, & suget be to hym as to a kynge & prynce of Irlan&dtail;.  And þat thys shol&dtail; be stydfastly I-hold, Macmorgh b&ydot;tok h&ydot;m h&ydot;s sone to astage, by so, þat yf he goo&dtail; pees hol&dtail;, & trewl&ydot; h&ydot;m helde, Oconghu&rtail; shold h&ydot;m yeue hys doghter to wyff.  Wha&ntail; thys was comynly I-shewed & I-knowe, & othes I-shwerne o&ntail; euery half, all th&ydot;s trewly to hold, Anothe&rtail; thyng was bespoke bytwen ham, bott þat preuely, that Macmorgh ne shol&dtail; nomore brynge vnked mon yn-to the lond, & thay that he hade y-broght, as rathe as he had leynestre y&ntail; good pees, he shol&dtail; anoon send ayenne home, & delyueryd þe lond of ham.

9.1:
Aftyr that þe pees was thys Imaket, þe host departed, euery o&ntail; h&ydot;s half.  Sone þer-after come Moryce, Geraudes so&ntail;, Robertes brothe&rtail;, of whom we spoke&ntail; ar thys, wyth .x. kn&ydot;ghtes & .xxx. Squyres & ij houndred footmen, & ar y ued at weysford; 
 A man fu&llbar; queynt, trow trogℏ al thynge, & stalwarth, & stydfast of word, & of hert symple, & shamffast as a mayd.  Wa&ntail; Macmorgh & Robert hyt wysten, thay weren ful glad, & bolde&rtail; þan thay before were: thay come to ham sone wyth þe oste þat thay had. Macmorgh be-thoght hy&mtail; of the mych vnryght that þe men of deuel&ydot;n>ail; h&ydot;m hadden done, & hys fade&rtail; all-so, man&ydot; sithe: he assembled h&ydot;s hostes, & redied hym to wend thedere.  Boot Robert byleft with somdell of þe me&ydot;ne, fore to rere hym a castell at a place that me clepeth þe karryke, & ys twey myle out of weysford; & Moryce went wyth h&ydot;m.  Macmorgh, as mayster & leder of the host, & cheuetayn of al. In lytell whyle, all þe contreys about dyuelyn, wyth robynge & bernyng & sle&ydot;ng, weren neght I-broght to nogℏt.  The site&yogh;eyns of dyuylyn, whan thay thys wysten, thay sentten to ham, & besoghten pees, & yaue ham so mych gold & syluer that non end was at har wylle, & good ostages, & othes I- s wore that þay sholden to Macmorgh trew be, & h&ydot;m knowleche þan-forward as lord & prynce.  Fro that tyme that thys was y-do, ther was noon Iryshman yn leynneste&rtail;, of hey kyne ne of low, that for seruesse for ferdnesse? of englyssemen ne yeldet hym to Macmorgh, so þat þer was noght of þe lon&dtail;-folke þat all nas subyett to hym, & redy to hys wylle.

10.1: IN thys whyle, wax a grett wreth & a grete stryfe betwyx þe kyn>ail; of Connaght, & donoll Obrey&ntail;, þe kyng of lymeryke, & of thomond. the kyng of connaght, Oconoghu&rtail;, gaddere&dtail; hys hostes for to wer&rtail; vpo&ntail; Obreen.  Obreen sent to mamorrow&yogh;, for allyaunce that was betwen ham, that he shold hym helpe. he spake þer-of to Robert & to Moryce, & bad ham that þay shol&dtail; go theder for to helpe Obreen.  Thay name har me&ntail; wyth ham, & wenten ynto thomon&dtail;, and ffonde&ntail; Oconoghu&rtail;, that stryffly stode ayey&ntail; ham, & many fyghtes ham yaue.  Bot the dysconfitu&rtail; turned vpo&ntail; Oconoghu&rtail;, & many of hys me&ntail; wer I-sley&ntail;, so that wythe shame he most turne ayey&ntail; ynto Connaght.  And fro that tym, Obreen wythdrow hym fro&mtail; Oconoghu&rtail;, & neuer after was subyect to hy&mtail; as he was tha&rtail;-by-fore; & the englysh hoste, wyth grett gettynges & with rych yiftes, turned ayeyne y&ntail;-to leynestre.

11.1:
Macmoro&yogh;w&yogh;ch sawe the englysshe-men so stalwarth that no power m&ydot;ght ham wythston&dtail;. he bethoght hy&mtail; of thynge that was passed, & that sume of hys eldre to-fore hy&mtail; hadde&ntail; somtyme the kynge-dome of all Irlan&dtail;, & that al the lond was subyet to hym: he wold, by h&ydot;s myght, by ryght of hys eldre&ntail;, brynge hyt yn-to the self state, that al þe lon&dtail; shold be vnde&rtail; hys lordshyppe, as hyt was wndre hys eldre&ntail; to-fore h&ydot;s t&ydot;m.  Of þys t&ydot;ng&etail; he spak preuely w&ydot;th Robert, & wyth Moryce, & besoght har consa&ydot;ll therof; And þay hy&mtail; answerd, & seide&ntail;, that 'l&ydot;ghtly that m&ydot;ght be done, yf he wold make come more plente of englyssh me&ntail; ynto þe lond.' he bad ham well þorwe, that thay sholden yn al manere senden after more of har ky&ntail; & frendshype. & for thay shol&dtail; the bettyre wyll haue the&rtail;-to, he profre&dtail; ha&mtail; to yeue hys eldest doghtre to on of ham, whych hyre so wold, wyth all hys lond aftyr h&ydot;s da&ydot;. bot, fore euery of ham had wyf & I-spoused that tyme, after mych spech, & many dalyaunce ther-of at thys consaylle, thay thoght þat he, to the erle Rychard, (of whom we haue ar thys I-spoke, & to whom he behete the same doghter ther-to-fore at Brystowe,) hys lettres shold send on th&ydot;s maner: "¶ Dermot Macmorgh, priynce of leynestre, to Rychard, Gylbertes so&ntail;, erle of strugo&ydot;l, sendeth grettynge.  If þou rekenest the tyme that ys Igoo, as well as we that nede haue, ou&rtail; mone nys ycome to þe no rather tha&ntail; hys tyme.  Storkes & swalewes, & oþer somer foules, we haue aft&ydot;re I-loked: thay come&ntail;, & wyth þe cold north-westre w&ydot;nd þay ben awey ywent.  Bot thy comynge, that we so mych haue desyred & so longe I-loked after, nether estren wyn d e, ne noon other, vs ne hath I-send, as thou vs be-hete.  þerfor, that thou ne hast y-dene troght some grete lette, hastyl&ydot; be about to do; for that we&rtail; al ou&rtail; gladnes, that thou hast swyth.  If þou stalwardly comest, & wyth good myght, the fou&rtail; partyes of Irland shal sone be turned to þe fyft."  Whan the erle had thys I-hard, he was yn many thoghtes; & aftyr many selcouth & dyuers redes, at the last he bethoght hym, that so fewe me&ntail; as were&ntail; yn-to the lond I-come the&rtail;-to-fore, hadde&ntail; y&ntail; so lytyll wh&ydot;ll so well I-sped of har aduentures: he name to hym the better herte, & thynge
 that he douted myche the&rtail;-by-fore to begyne, he wax tho the bolder to tak an hond.  Fro that tyme, al h&ydot;s thoght & all hys w&ydot;lle was, nyghte & day, wyth a&llbar; hys my&yogh;th to wen&dtail; in-to Irlan&dtail;. He went hym to þe kyn>ail; henry, & hym swith be-soght þat he shol&dtail; delyuer hym hys londes þat sholden be hys by ryght of herytage, other yeue hym leue to do hym yn adventu&rtail;, lon&dtail; to purchace y&ntail; vnked lan&dtail;.

12.1:
Whan the Kynge wyst hys entent, whoder he wold go, he ne yaue hym fully leue, ne fully hym ne warned; bot wyth such leue as he had, he dight hym þe wynter ty&llbar; the begynny n ge of Maye.  He sent to-for hym ynto Irland A knyght that was I-called Reymon&dtail; le gras;—wyth hym, x knytghtes, & fourty Squyers, & four score bowmen;—A man ful hardy & stalwarde, & we&llbar; proued y&ntail; wepne, Robertis neueu, & Moryces, har eldest brother, sone.  Thay arryued at a place i-called dundoneuile, four myle a soutℏ halfe Waterford; & ther thay arered a dyche, & a feble castel vpon, of yardes and turues .  The men of Watterford, & wyth ham Malaghely&ntail; of olan, thys waren I-ware that thay y-hadden such negℏborhede ful loth, & toke ha&mtail; to rede, þat þay wolden vpo&ntail; ha&mtail;, ar mo com to ham.  Thay assembled ham togeddre, well thre thousand me&ntail;, & wente&ntail; ouer the wattyr of sur, that parteth the twey contres of leynestre & of mounestre, & sette&ntail; ha&mtail; y&ntail; thre hostes, ful boldely for to assaylle the englysshe-me&ntail; with-In har castell.  Reymond & hys me&ntail;—thogh they fewe wer, the&ydot; we&rtail; nat fe&ydot;nt—with vneuenl&ydot; host wente&ntail; out & assembled wyth ham.  Bot, as no wonde&rtail; was, so few men ne myght nat all priuely f&ydot;ghten a&ydot;ey&ntail; so many, thay turned ha&mtail; aye to har recet. the other wenede&ntail; that thay departed &ydot;n d&ydot;scomfyte; tha&ydot; brake&ntail; har sheld. I&ntail;, & wentte&ntail; aftyr: & thay war nat fully wythy&ntail; þe yate, that some of ha&mtail; ne&rtail; rathe&rtail; In tha&ntail; þe englyssh.  Reymond saw that he & hys were&ntail; y&ntail; gret perylle, & vpon poynt to lese the lyfe. he be-cryed hys felewes, & turned stalwarthly vpo&ntail; he&rtail; forme&ntail; men in front. ; & þe fyrste that come y&ntail;, he claue hy&mtail; the heed, & throgℏ slaght of that 
 ma&ntail;, all the ost was dyscomfyte, & tok ha&mtail; to flyght.  The oþer ham folwed y&ntail;-to all þe pley&ntail;, & leyd ha&mtail; o&ntail; so, þat y&ntail; lytell wh&ydot;ll thay slowe of ha&mtail; fyfe hundred & mo; & þe most parte of þe othe&rtail; felle&ntail; ado&ntail; y&ntail;-to þe see, of þe heye rokes, & drent ha&mtail;-selfe.  In thys fyght, was a knyght that hete Wyllya&mtail; ferand, that dydde ouer-we&llbar; & aboue all othe&rtail;: he was a ma&ntail; that hade semblant as thoght he we&rtail; o&ntail; the mich yuell, & þer-fo&rtail; he put hy&mtail;- selue alwey the&rtail; the most perille was; ffor he ne raght thegh deth come betwene hy&mtail; & h&ydot;s &ydot;uell, ar hyt wa&rtail; to mych I-sm&ydot;t vpo&ntail; hy&mtail;.  He&rtail; þe pryd of waterford felle; he&rtail; a&llbar; h&ydot;s m&ydot;ght went to noght; he&rtail;-of come the Englysshe hope & comfort; & to the Iresshe, dred & wanhope; ffor h&ydot;t was neuer the&rtail;-to-for I-herd, that of so fewe men, so grett a slaght was done. Bot lyder consaylle thay d&ydot;dde&ntail; þe&rtail;-after, that turned ham to mych cruelte; ffor wha&ntail; the ma&ydot;str&ydot; was al har, & al har fome&ntail; ouercome, In þe fyght were&ntail; ytake well thre score me&ntail; & te&ntail;, that ham yolde&ntail;, & were&ntail; the heghest & the rychyst of al the sitè, such þat þay m&ydot;ght haue had for ham the sitè delyuered, or els as myche catel as thay wolden desy&rtail;.  Heruy of Mountmorthy, that to ha&mtail; was &ydot;come, h&ydot;m thrydsome of kn&ydot;ghtes, & Reymond, vp dyuers domes stroue&ntail; what me&ntail; shol&dtail; do wyth har prysons pryson=prisoner. ; ffor Reymond trauayllet about for to dylyuere ha&mtail;, as a ma&ntail; of reuthful mode, & þus seyd to hys feres: "lordynges, what ys vs to done of ou&rtail; wreched prisoners?  I sey nat that man shal on any maner spa&rtail; hys foma&ntail;; bot thay beth nat now fomen, both but: Sed hi non hostes jam, sed homines .— Op . v. 250. beth me&ntail; nat rebelle, bot y&ntail; bataylle for to defend har contrey ouercome.  Me thynketh thay beth now y&ntail; such state, that me oght bettyr haw mercy of ha&mtail; & yeve ha&mtail; lyfe, for to yeue othe&rtail; ensample to be boxo&mtail;, tha&ntail; cruely to do ha&mtail; to deth, wha&rtail;-throgℏ þat othe&rtail;, throgℏ ferdnesse of trust, þe lasse to yel&dtail; ha&mtail; to vs."  Wha&ntail; Reymon&dtail; had such wordes I-seyde, yn al þe folke was moste wi lle The ink has perisht: ' et murmure populi cum quodam quasi favore subsecuto .' Gir. Camb., Exp. Hib . c. xv.— Op . v. 252, Rolls Series. to graunt ham lyf, Arose vp Heruy amonge 
 hame al, & thys ha&mtail; seyd: "Inogℏ Reymond openly to vs hath spoke of mercy & almes-dedes, vnked landes I-wonne, & nat wyth slagℏ & wyth brenny n ge.  Whede&rtail; Alexande&rtail; & Iulius Cesar, that were&ntail; lordes of al þe worl&dtail;, wonnen londes by such wey, I wold Reymond wold me answer.  Whan thay come&ntail; to vs vel arrayede to fyghte&ntail;, If þay hadde I-won ouer-hand & vs ouercome, wolden thay, for almesse & for reuth, haw had mercye of vs? nay, I trow nat.  þerfor out-chese o&ntail; of two: Othe&rtail; do manly thynge, whe&rtail;-fore we bene ycome; & the folke þat ys rebbe&llbar; ayeyn vs, wyth-outten any noyse, wyth wepne hertely brynge out of dawes; Other, yf we sholle&ntail; do almes dede on he&mtail;, & ha&mtail; spare&ntail;, as Reymond hath seyd, out we wend to ou&rtail; shyppes, & turne ayey&ntail;, & let we the wreched men hold har lond, & brouken wythouten any chalange."  Heruyes dome lyket bettre than Reymondes; & weren the Cyte&yogh;eyns to deth Idemed.  Thay ne hadden no wone of warytres; & þerfor þey ladden ha&mtail; to þe clyf of þe see, & put ha&mtail; adoun, & drent ham.

13.1:
The men-tyme, the Erl Rychard, wyth the powe&rtail; that he had arayed, was y-come to south wales; & wha&ntail; he hadde wyth gret reuerence y-done hys pylrimage at sent dauyes, he put hym to saylle, & hade good wynd, came &ydot;nto Irland with two hundret knythtes & othe&rtail;, mo&rtail; than a thousand.  He arryued at weyseford on seynt Bertylmewes eue&ntail;: Than was fulfylled a prophecye that Merly&ntail; seyd of hys comynge; 'þe brond shal come to-fore þe borned fy&rtail;; And rygh as the spark maked the brond come, Also þe brond shal make the fyr come after.'  Anoþer prophecye, seynt Molynge seyd of that same: 'A mych man shall erne to-fore; & þe most heeddes of desmond & ek of leynestre he shal defouly; & wyth streynth he shall noblych the wey opne to the wepned.'  Amorow, whan the tythynge of ha&mtail; was I-spronge, Reymond went hym to the Erle with furty knyghtes with mych gladnes; & amorow, after þe holy-daye, Thay went comynly al to þe syte of Waterford, & assaylled the toun ful fersly; & twyes thay were&ntail; rebuked, & ful stalwarhly, of þe Cyte&yogh;eyns. Reymond, that by purueaunce & graunt of ham al was ymade
 prince, & forma&ntail; of al the host, sawe & awayted a place good for to assaylle: he cryed & cleped the wepned men to the assaut, & þay egrely assayllede&ntail;, & brake&ntail; yn-to þe sytè, & folke-mele slowe the me&ntail; y&ntail; weyes & y&ntail; houses, & wa&ntail; þe Cyte.  In rathnyldes tou&rtail; were&ntail; twey ryche me&ntail; ytake, bot þrogℏ praye&rtail; of Macmorgℏ, that thede&rtail; was tha&ntail; I-come, he was y-hold alyue. Macmorgh brogℏt hys doghty&rtail; with hym, Eue by name, & spoused hy&rtail; to the Erle, & made&ntail; fast sekernesse betwe&ntail; ham.  Wa&ntail; thys was ydo al, þe Erle left me&ntail; for to kepe the cytè, & turned hym with the hoste to deuyly&ntail;.

14.1:
Macmorgℏ wyst that myche of the powe&rtail; of ha&rtail; lond was I-come to helpe&ntail; ha&mtail; of dyuely&ntail;, & hadde&ntail; beset all þe wodde weyes & þe narow weys thetherward: he left tho weyes, & lad the hoste throght the montaynes of Glyndelagℏ, al harmeles, ryght to the syte.  These cyte&yogh;eyns, ouer al othe&rtail;, hated were&ntail; of hym, & that was no wonde&rtail;; ffor yn some tyme thay slowe&ntail; hys fady&rtail; y&ntail; the cytè; & after the harme, thay dydde hy&mtail; mych sha&mtail;, fo&rtail; thay burryd an hounde with hym yn the pute that he was yn I-leyde.  Thay sent messagers to þe Erle, & namely the Erchebysshop laurence, & besoghte&ntail; pees; & as thay were&ntail; spekyng of pees, on oon half was Reymond, & on the othe&rtail; halue a ful hardy knyght, Myles of Cogan, with yonglynges well coueytouse of battaylle & of gettyng.  Thay assaylled the Cytè, & breken In, & wan þe Cytè, wyth gret slaght of þe syt&yogh;eyns. Natheles, the best parte of ham, wyth þe rychest & the derwarthest thyngys þat thay hadde&ntail;, yn botes escapeden, & wenten yn-to þe north ylondes, wyth hastoyl, that was maystre yn the cyte, & har lodesma&ntail;.  That day byfel two Muracles yn the cyte: that on of the Croice, yn the mode&rtail; ch&ydot;rche of þe tr&ydot;n&ydot;te, whyche the Cyt&yogh;eyns wolde&ntail; haue I-ladde with ham yn-to the ylandes yn the see; & for nothyn>ail;, thay ne myghth yt wecche&ntail; out of þe place.  That othe&rtail;, of a sergeant that hadde I-robbet the erchebysshoppes paleys, & þer-after come to-for þe rode, & offred a peny: fyrst, & efte-sone, & at euery tym, the peny stert ayeyne to hym. he bethoght hym that god was nat wel I-quenyted of the robbery
 that he had y-do: he turned hym than, & let take al that he had y-nom , & ba&rtail; hyt ayeyn, & went to þe rode & offred; & hy s offrynge the r abode.  Whan þe Erl hade a few dayes I-ordyned for the stat of þe Cytè, he left the&rtail; Myles de Cogan, keper of þe Cytè & of þe contre, & a partye of þe meyne wyth hym.  And by entycement of Macmorgh, that bethoght hym of þe old enmyte that he hade to the kynge of Mithe, he went hym to þe contrey, branten, slowen, & robeden, & broghten the contre to noght, for none ne durst hym wythe-stond.  Oconghu&rtail; of Conaght saw that he was the next—as man that seethe hys neghbors hous berne, he may drede of þe sparkes—he sent Messagers to Macmorgh yn thys wordes: "Ayeyne þe fou&rtail;me of ou&rtail; pees, thou hast imad come yn-to thys lond mych out-come&ntail; folke.  þe whylle that thou held the yn thy leynystre, we hyt tholleth euynly; Now thou, as man that naght ne the thynkest on thyn oth, ne no reuth ne hast of thyn ostage, the merres I-sete of thyn eldren lond, vnryghtfullyo uergoste.  Make thyn out-comen men wyth-draw, & turne ayeyne, or els sothly we shul the send thy sones heede."  Macmorgh thys herd, & yaf hy&mtail; a prout answa&rtail;, & sent hym to sey, that he ha&mtail; wold hold, & send after more & eke more; that he nold neuer reste tyl he hadde I-wonne Connaght, wyth the kynge-dome of al þe lond, as hys eldre&ntail; sumtym hyt hadde&ntail; to-fo&rtail; hym.  Oconnoghu&rtail; had he&rtail; of grete dyspyte, & sore was atened, & let smyth of sonnes heed, þat he had hym Itake fore ostage.

15.1:
Aftyr this, worth gret spech yn-to all þe lond, & mych ferdnesse of the out-come&ntail; me&ntail;.  Than gaddered ham al to-gedderes, al the clerkes & the wysme&ntail; of þe lond at ardmagℏ; & of thys folkes comyn>ail;, was mych I-spoke, & longe dalyaunce.  At þe laste, comynly thay accordede&ntail; al he&rtail;-to, that, for the sy&ntail; of þe folk, thys mesaduentu&rtail; ham ys byfal; namely, that whan thay fonde&ntail; englysshe-me&ntail; chyldren to sylle&ntail;, that chepmen & robbers woldene brynge to the lond, thay were wonet to by ham, & do ham y&ntail; thraldome; & that throgh goddys owne 
 wreth hyt was, that as syllers were&ntail; to-fore y-broght yn thraldome, also the byggers sholden after: ffo&rtail; hyt was somty&mtail; that the folke of englond—The maner of har kyngdome was al I-hole—whan thay had no&ntail; othe&rtail; thynge that þay myghten take to, ratha&rtail; than thay wold any myssayse tholy, Thay we&rtail; I-wont to sylle&ntail; ha&rtail; chyldren & ha&rtail; othe&rtail; kynnesme&ntail;, botℏ ynto Irlond & ynto othe&rtail; londes.  The&rtail;-fo&rtail; hyt may well be soth, that as the byggers, also þe syllers, oft serued wel, throgℏ so loly gyltes to be y-broght yn thraldome. The&rtail; hyt was yn þat consaylle be-heght, & by assent of al comynly I-set, that al the englysshe-me&ntail; yn þe lond that yn thraldome were&ntail;, shold be&ntail; delyuered, & frely let goo whody&rtail;so they wold.

16.1: Her-aftyr spronge tythyngges of the Erle & of þe englysshe-me&ntail; ynto englond; &, as maner ys, myche me made more; & that the Erl hade apropred to hym, nat only leynestre, bot othe&rtail; londes also, that, by no ryght ne by law, to hy&mtail; ne to hys wyf longe&ntail;.  The kynge sent anoon, & forebeed that, 'out no lond that were yn hys powe&rtail;, ne shold no shyppen passe yn-to Irland, ne no maner thynge for to brynge; & al me&ntail; that yn-to Irland wa&rtail; comen, shold ayeyn come yn-to englande, wyth-yn þe next estre, o&rtail; they sholden be dysheryted & ex y led out of lond for euer.'  The Erl saw that he & hys were&ntail; narow belad, both of hys men that hym wold leue, & eke that nothynge ne most hym come out of othe&rtail; landes, of þynge that hym nede was: by comune rede of hys men, he sent Reymond ouer to the kynge that was fe&rtail; yn gascoyne, & thus hym sent to say: "By thy leue, lord, yf y am welle vndyrstond, y went ynto Irland for to help thy trew man, Dermot Macmorgh; þerfor, that al that of hys herytage, othe&rtail; of oþers yn þe lond, almyghty god me hath I-sent, as hyt come of thy graunt & of thy good wylle, also, I wyll that hyt to the turne, to do the&rtail;-wyth what the lyketh."

17.1:
Reymond went to the kynge with such mandement; & the whyle that he folwed the kynges court, abydynge hys answe&rtail;, Thomas, the erchebyssho&pmacr;&pmacr;ē of Cantrebery ( In margin, in a later hand : The archebushop of canterbury called Tho. Beckett.  1171.) , was martyred 
 yn englond, nat wyth-out mych blame to al þe lond-folk, both lered & lewed.  That erchebysshopp, after many-fold martyrdome that he þolled, negh seuen ye&rtail; that he was banshed out of englond for the ryghtes of holy chyurche, In sore & many wepynges, yn double hee&rtail; about hys body—þat o&ntail;, yn styd of shyrth; that oþer, yn stydde of breche—nyght & day yn holy praye&rtail; & redynge yn holy wrytte; & o thynge that meste sorow broght to hys hert, that al hys ky&ntail;, men & wommen, yonge & old, wommen lyggyne yn chyld-bed, & old men that fore eld yroked weren yn he&rtail; cradelys, & all othe&rtail;, clerkes & lewed, that me myght wytt that sybrede or othe&rtail; frendshypp hadde&ntail; to hym, al thay were&ntail; I-dryue out of englond; & al they that were&ntail; of eld that þay myghty othes swer&rtail;, swaren vpon the masse-boke that, as sone as thay come ouer the see, thay shold go to þe erchebysshō&pmacr;&pmacr;ē,  & shew hym the wrechednesse that þay suffred for hys sake; ffor he shol&dtail;, for reuth of ham, turnen hys hert, & graunt þe kynges wylle of þynge that he desyred.  After such martyrdomes, and many othe&rtail; þat he tholled yn hys lyue, whyche no manly hert may bethynke to ful end, the hey martyrdome, that broght hys soule to þe blysse of heuyn, & hys body to wyrshyppe yn hert, othe&rtail; many þynges be-t&ydot;dden that men Aght well vnderstond; þat ayeyns hys fomen yede, opyn heed, & opened þe chyrch dur&rtail; whyche the monkes hadden I-loke, & seyd þat 'me&ntail; ne shold no castell make of holy chyrche'; & hys holy croune bade ayeyn the naked swerdes for to smyte, & that yn the modyr chyrche, heghest of al þe lond, & to-fo&rtail; the weued, that he of fou&rtail; knyghtes, wode&rtail; than wood houndes, tholled fou&rtail; woundes yn the holy croun, & n on without,—so as þe croun ogℏt betokne of proteccion to clergy,—that he deth tholled yn the north syde of þe chyrche, whyche betokneth Ihesu crystes passyo&ntail;. & thus goddys owne knyghte, wythouten any ferdnesse, tholled deth; yn hys lyf of thys world, chaunged wel selyly for þe lyf that euer shal lest without end.  And as seynt Tomas-ys day, Apostle, ys þe fyft day afor yold, so ys thys Thomas day þe fyft day afte&rtail;.  That Thomas was candel I-set yn þe este of þe world; Thys Thomas yn þe west. That was lyght to aly chyrche yn hy&rtail; yough, as Thys yn hy&rtail; eld;
 & as he the Apostle commenced holy chyrche with hys blode whan che was arerynge, Also thys, Beket, whan she had longe I-stond & wox yn eld, & redy was to falle, wyth hys blode he ryght hyr vp, & sette hyr yn ryght stydde.  And as he t oke hym selue to quellers ffor to are&rtail; þe seknes of holy chyrche, also thys ne douten nat to take&ntail; hym-self to kene swerdes, & lydde&rtail; men hondes, fo&rtail; þe fredome of holy chyrche to sawe vnwemmed.  The fourme of hys martyrdome, twey verses a latyn shortly comprehendeth, that thus mych ben to vnderstond: "ffo&rtail; crystes spouse, vnder crystes tyme, yn crystes chyrche, crystes owne leman deyed."  Amonge al the halwe&ntail; that almyghty god wroght yn erth, of selcouth myrac&lbar;ys for to showe&ntail; ha&rtail; holynesse,—as the blynd to see, the lame to go&ntail;, þe dombe to speke, the deue to hy&rtail;, lasers to clense, paralys to festnen, y-dropesie & al othe&rtail; manere yueles to hele&ntail;, the dede to areren, yuel gostes to quethe&ntail;, & al þe fou&rtail; elementes to ha&rtail; commaundement hadde&ntail;,—he alo&ntail; was y-wyrshypped with al these, & more þer-to, tha&rtail;-to-fo&rtail; that tofore was nat herd ne sey; ffo&rtail; a ma&ntail; that hade hys eghen I-draw out of hys heed, & hys manly menbres y-kytte of & y-cast awey, come to hys tombe; & þrogℏ besechyn>ail; of hym, god hym sent newe.  Of thys holy marty&rtail;, Merlyn seyd thus yn hys prophecye: "A newe marty&rtail; shal aryse with newe myracles, that yn the worldes endyn>ail;, yn the west of þe world, by specyal vertue, mannys lymmes out I-draw & out I-corue, ayeyn shald make come.  Sorow shal turne ynto yoye, wha&ntail; þe sonnes shal sle þe fady&rtail; yn hys mody&rtail; wombe; prynces & hey men shal come out of þe este yn-to the weste, & lout ham to þe newe martyres fot-stappes."  Al þys was openly I-seyd of þe holy marty&rtail; seynt Thomas; he was þe whet corne þat fel yn erth, & mych fruyt forth broght.  In þe ye&rtail; of burth-tyme .xlviij.; of hys sacryfiynge .viij.; of hys exil .vij.; yn the end of Decembre, yn þe yere of ou&rtail; lordes yncarnacion .M.C.lxxj.; & was poppe of Rome, Alexandre the thyrd; Emperou&rtail; of Almayne, ffrytheryke; kynge of ffraunce, lowys.  Whan the wentyr was I-passed, Dermot Macmorgh deyed, þe begynenyn>ail; of may, & was bured at ffernes. A man grett of body; hardy yn fyght amonge hys folke; of lange & lome cryynge yn fyght, hys voys was somdel hors; leuer hym 
 was that man hym dredet than loued; þe noble & þe ryche he wold brynge to noght; the mek MS. mok.  Lat. ' humilium erector .' & the pouer he wold rere; al men ayeyns hym, & he ayeyns al.

18.1:
Aftyr that, about whyt-sontyde, hastoyl, that was some tyme maystre of deuylyn,—as man that fayn was about for to awreke hys old tene,—come wyt men of northwey & of þe north ylondes, with ful grett folk, yn furty grett shyppes, & arryued yn þe hauen of amlyffy, with ha&rtail; lodes-ma&ntail;, that hete Ioℏn the Wood.  Thay wenten out of ha&rtail; shyppes, men well I-wepned, sum with longe swerdes, some with Iren pletes & round sheldes well I-bound about with Iren, swerdes & speres & axys ynowe, & come&ntail; well ordeynly fo&rtail; to assaylle the toun on the eest half. Miles de Cogan, kepe&rtail; of þe Cyte, kyndly stalwardly, & hardy, wyth wel chose&ntail; folke, went out ayeyns ham, and yaf ham fyght; bot stron>ail; hyt was, to hold fyght ayayn so many with so fewe: tha&ntail; had he I-lost some of hys me&ntail;; & O knyghtes theygℏ was I-cut with þe kappe of hys haubergeo&ntail; wytht a dynt of a dennysℏ ax.  nede he most turne y&ntail; ayeyne at þe yate, tyll that Rychar&dtail; de Cogan, Myles brothe&rtail;, wythe few men, that whylle stylly went out at the south yate, & sharply becryed ham behynd, & smote vpon ham. throgh that, þat he come so fersly vpon ham, thay we&rtail; so afrygh, that thay wyst nat o&ntail; whych syde thay shold kepe the fyght: yn a lytell whyl thay wa&rtail; dyssconfyte, & toke ham to flyght toward ha&rtail; shyppes.  these othe&rtail; come ham betwene, & slowe ful many: the&rtail; was Joℏn the Wood I-slayn, & ful mych folk wyth hym, throght Walter de Redlesford, that ful stalwarth was yn the fyght.  Hascoyl was I-take fro the shyppe the&rtail; he was to I-flow, & I-broght alyues yn-to the Cyte, & hys lyf I-graunted for raunceo&ntail;; bot as he stode yn court to-fo&rtail; Myles, he put forth lyddyrly a prout word & seyd, "wyt lytell powe&rtail; we comen now, & thys nas bot assaye of our myght; bo t yf I lyue, a&rtail; hyt be lange to, shal come othe&rtail; so mych as þese."  Whan thys was I-har&dtail;—for y&ntail; the mannys tonge hys oft lyf & deth, & me seyth eke, 'Ton>ail; breketh bo&ntail;, thegh hym-self ne hawe none'—Myles bad that 
 men shold hym anoo&ntail; out lede, & smyte of þe heed.  & thus, fo&rtail; hys hauteyn & prout spech, he lost þe lyf that tha&rtail;-by-fo&rtail; mekely hym was graunted.

19.1:
Sone aftyr thys, many of thay that weren y-come yn-to Irland wyth the Erl, & eke to-fore,—for the kynges byddynge that come to ham, as hyt ys to l d a-foo&rtail;,—leften the Erl, & wente&ntail; yn-to england.  The peple of yrland saw the erl narow beladde, both of hys me&ntail; That hym left, & of vytalle that trukked, whe&rtail;-of he hade grete plente the&rtail;-by-fore out of england. Thay gaddered ham to-gedders myche folk, al þe prynce of the lond, with al ha&rtail; poe&rtail;, & besegeden deuely&ntail; o&ntail; euery halue; & that was throgh procuryn>ail; of laurence, Erchebysshoppe of dyuely&ntail;, as men seyd, for loue of hys folk.  he sent also hys lettres, with Oconghours lettres, kynge of Connaght, to Gothred, kyn>ail; of Manne, & to othe&rtail; prynces of þe nortℏ ylondes, for to be-sete the hauy&ntail; of dyuely&ntail;; & large yiftes & presentes ham yaue, & myche more hem behete, for to helpe ham.  &, for thay drede ham of al such manere of aventures, Throgh that, that the englysshe-men hadden so wel I-conquered vpo&ntail; þe yrysshe, Thay come&ntail; the rather ham to help; & yn lytell whyle came .xxx ti . shyppys ful of stalwarth men wel arayed to fyght, & besette&ntail; the haue&ntail; of amlyffy.  Whan the Erl & hys men were&ntail; well twey monthes beley&ntail; yn the syte of dyuelyn, & to ham come non helpe, nethe&rtail; of þe lond ne on waty&rtail;, & vytaylle fast ham slaked; & (as hyt ys oft I-found, selde be-falleth oo&ntail; harme that more ne come ) come Donald, Macmorghes sone, of okenseley, to The Erl, & told hym for that Robert steuenes-son was beseget yn hys castell that he had rered at þe carryke, of þe Cyte&yogh;eyns of weysford & the men of kensely, well þre thousand men; & few men had wyth hy&mtail;; &, but hym come socours by the þryd day, that of hym, ne thay that with hym were&ntail;, neuer no more to thynke.  In the syte of dyuelyn, we&rtail; that tyme be-left with the erl, Moryche fytz-Geraud & Reymond, that fro&mtail; the kynge was come&ntail; newly; sory for ham-self & for hars: & thegh þey weren yn grett angwysshe fo&rtail; ham-seleue, thay ware&ntail; y&ntail; wel more fo&rtail; ha&rtail; good brothe&rtail; & for hys, that amonge
 hys fomen was beseyget, yn place febly I-garnset, but a dych & a hegge of thornes vpo&ntail;, & lytell ost ston-wal.  Moryce arose vp to-fore the erl & the knyghtes, & seyde:  "Nat to delytes, ne ydelnes set to drawen, come we nat yn-to thys lande; both but. for to sechen aduentures, & prouen ou&rtail; streynth vpon peryl of ou&rtail; heedes.  We haue I-stond awhyle & heghest, & now we bene y-turned to the lowest, for so goth þe sykenesse of thys world; euery gladnesse ys endet wyth sorowe, & euery selth hath wnselth at þe end.  After þe bryght day, cometh the durke nyght; & after, the durknesse of þe nyght ys awey I-dryuen with þe lyght of þe sone.  Ar thys, the ouer-hand was yn all styddes ou&rtail;, & plente of alle good; nowe beth so beloke&ntail;, that non help vs ne may come, noþer by lond ne by waty&rtail;.  On oþer halue, Robert steuenes-sone, whos herdy herth opened vs þe wey yn-to þys land, ys beseged fe&rtail; wyt hys fome&ntail; y&ntail; folk place.  What ybyde we? haue we any hope that ou&rtail; lond-folk vs come to helpe? tha&rtail;-to ne tryst we nat; fo&rtail; we beth now yn such law I-sette, þat as þe Iresshe we&rtail;, a&rtail; thys, to the englyshe, also þe englysshe beth now to þe Iresshe.  tha&rtail;-fo&rtail; gow owt stalwartly, assayllen ou&rtail; fomen! thegh we few be, we be&ntail; me&ntail; of herth, & wel I-wepned! ne shal neuer naked rascayll, thegh þey many be, haue myght ne powe&rtail; vs to wyt-stond."  Whan moryce hadde thys I-seyd, Reymond, þat was I-smyte wyth the same sorow of herth, seyd to ham þe same wordes, & mych mo&rtail;, 'that thay wollde&ntail; allerformest smyth vpon þe kyn>ail; of konnaght, & hym that was heed, & formest & heghest of ham alle.'  Al that the&rtail; were&ntail;, helde&ntail; herto, & ren astryf to wepne ham, & leppe&ntail; to hors, & deled ham a thre, thegh thay fewe were&ntail;.  In þe formest, was Reymond with twonty knyghtes; In þe othe&rtail;, myles wyth .xxx ti .; In þe þryd, the Erl & morice, with fourty knyghtes & Squyerys; & men an-hors & a-foot, to euery of these I-sete, as hyt wold by-falle: thay went ham out of þe syte stylly, about noon-dayes, & with so few me&ntail; assayllyde&ntail; a&ntail; hostes of .xxx ti . thousand.  Reymond, amonge the fyrst, smote vpon ham; & fey&rtail; to-fo&rtail; al othe&rtail;: he smote tweyne throgh-out wyth a spee&rtail;.  Reymond & Moryce twey sonnes, Geraud & Alexande&rtail;, 
 thegh thay we&rtail; fyrst y-sete yn þe latest of þe host, throgh kynd stalwardnesse hertly smytte&ntail; out to the formest, & many dydden to deth.  Alle þe othe&rtail; fresshely foloweden afte&rtail;; & yn lytell whylle dysconfited al þe hoste, & slowe&ntail; so many, that no tonge ne myght tell.  Oconnoghou&rtail;, þat that tym satte yn bathe, vnnethe escaped: thay folwed the dyscomfytu&rtail; o&ntail; euery halue tyll þe nyght ham leth.  Than thay turned ayeyne, & name ha&rtail; pelfre, gold & syluy&rtail;, clothes & wepne & hors, & wente&ntail; wyth mychel gladnesse yn-to þe syte.  Amorow þay lefte good kypynge yn the syte, & turneden toward weysford by Odroon, wyth baners y-lacet, fo&rtail; to socou&rtail; Robert steuenes-sone.

20.1:
The mene time, the folke of Weysford, wythe þe powe&rtail; of Okensely, wel thre þousand men, ayeyn ha&rtail; othes I-swe&rtail; & ha&rtail; trowth, Robert steuenesso&ntail; al vnwardly, with fyue knyghtes & a few bow-men I-found withyn hys feble castel, thay stynt nat to assaylle. thay defendet ham full stalwarthly, thegh they fewe we&rtail;; & namely a knyght that hete Wyllyam Not, afty&rtail; Robert, ouer al othe&rtail; best dydde.  Whan thay myght nat wyth streynth spede, thay bethoght ham that wyth falshed & wyth treyson they wold come wyth-yn ham.  Thay sent to þe dyche twey bysshoppes, that on of Weysford, that othe&rtail; of kylda&rtail;, & othe&rtail; mo wyth ham yn habyt of relygyo&ntail;; thay broght with ham massebokes, & Corpus domini, & relykes many, & sworne vp-on ham al, & vpo&ntail; ha&rtail; owne soules, that 'dyuelyn was Itak; & þe Erl & morice & Remond, & the englisshe-men, euerychon I-slawe; the host of leynestre & of Connaght comyng to ham-ward; & for good of hym, thay we&rtail; to hym y-come; that he shold yeld vp his castel, & me shold saue hym lyf & lym, & al his & al har good; for he was ham so fre & so meke lord, me shold trewly brynge hym & his ouer in-to Wales ar the grete hoste of his fomen to hym comen, that nothyng nold spa&rtail; hym.'  Robert leued ha&rtail; speche & ha&rtail; fals othes; he came out & yeldet hym & his, to ham & to ha&rtail; trowth.  Thay we&rtail; no raþer out I-comen, that me ne name ham euerychone; & some thay slowen yn þe place; some þay vndide & betten lidderly & bonden; & wyth ham selfe I-bounden, kesten
 willych In preson.  Nat lon>ail; the&rtail;-after, come soth tythyngges of the dysconfytu&rtail; of dyuelyn, & the Erles comyn>ail; toward ham. the thraytours, whan thay hyt wyste&ntail;, thay setten ha&rtail; own toun of weysford afy&rtail;, & barnen hyte; & wente&ntail; ham-self, with wyf & chyld, & al ha&rtail; oþer good & ha&rtail; presons, ynto þe Iland of beggeryn>ail;, þat hys I-sete yn the entre of the hauen of Weysford.  Þe host of leynester come ayeyns hym yn Odrone, & yaf hym fyght yn a paas of o thykke wood, strange yn hym selue, & comerous. The&rtail; we&rtail; many of the Irysshe y-slaw yn that fyght; & þe Erl & al hys came&ntail; hole & sound yn-to þe pleyne, sawe o man that he þer forlese; & meyle&rtail;, ou&rtail; al othe&rtail;, as hys wone was, stalwardly hym tha&rtail; byladde.  ¶ After that, as thay comy&ntail; toward Weysford, come&ntail; me&ntail; ayeyns ham, & tolden ham the aduentu&rtail; of Robert, & of the toū&nmacr;es bernyn>ail;, & seyde&ntail; ham sykerly, that 'yf þay to ham wold vend anoon, þay wold sle ha&rtail; presons, & send ham the heeddes.'  Wha&ntail; thus was y-hard amon>ail; the oste, who-so had I-hard þe wepynge, & the wenynge, & the sorow that thay mad, he myght wel sygge that 'neuer-more sych reuth was amonge me&ntail; I-sey.' he was ma&ntail; that noon othe&rtail; was hys eunynge In all goodnesse O virum, virtutis unicum, verique laboris exemplum .— Op . v. 271. , & ensampell to all knyghtes that any stalwarthnesse wold begynnyge; ffor yn Wales & eke yn Irland many aduentures both god & yuel had I-fond, that ofte&rtail; weren hys aduentures hard, thegh thay som tyme welcome&ntail; wyth hym.  He was man mych of body, fayr vysage, soft & rody, nat ful becumliche; grete meet-yeuer, large & fre throgℏ al thynge, & of grett solace yn Iappynge & pleynge; bot to mych, & vnmesurable, he yaf hymself lecherye "fayr vysage, soft & rody, nat ful becumliche; grete meet-yeuer, large & fre throgℏ al thynge, & of grett solace yn Iappynge & pleynge; bot to mych, & vnmesurable, he yaf hymself lecherye" = vultuque decenti; et statura paulo mediocritatem excedente: vir dapsilis et largus, liberalis et jocundus, sed vino Venerique trans modestiam datus .— Op . v. 271-2. .  The Erl was man of suche manere; he was samroed, with grey eghen, wommanes vysage, & sproty, smal spech, short nek "he was samroed, with grey eghen, wommanes vysage, & sproty, smal spech, short nek" = Vir subrufus, lentiginosus, oculis glaucis, facie feminea, voce exili, colls contracto .—Gir. Camb. Op . v. 272.  Rolls Series. ; on al othe&rtail; manere he was of fay&rtail; body, & alonge fre & meke; ham that he hade nat to yeue to, he quemed ham with fay&rtail; spech: out of wepne, he was as redy to otheres byddynge 
 as othe&rtail; to hys: alle thynge he dydde by rede of hys me&ntail;, & nothynge wyth-out.  Out of bataylle, he had more of knyght tha&ntail; of host-lede&rtail;; yn bataylle, more lede&rtail; than knyght; & yn al aduenturs of bataylle, he was stydfast, ful connynge, & tokne of recet to al hys host; & for no&ntail; vnhap he ne amayed hymself, ne yn wanhope ne fel; ne for ne good chaunce, he ne made hym the prutter ne þe more hautay&ntail;; bot euer-more, yn al aduen tu rs, of stydfast herth & trewe.

21.1:
Whan the erl hadde I-hard the trayson þat was I-done to Robert, wytht myche sorow of hert he went hym with the host to Watyrford; & þer he fond heruy of mountmorthy, that tha&ntail; wase newe&ntail; I-come&ntail; out of englond fro&mtail; þe kynge, & broght wryttes, & eke by mych amonested the erl that he shold wend to the kynge.  he hade shyppe redy, & good wynd; he name heruy with hym, & went ouer; come to the contre of clandechestre, to Newenham, ther he fond the kynge with mychel host, redy to pass y&ntail;-to Irland. & after myche speche betwene ham ymade, & myche dalyaunce, throgh heruyes modelyng & comynge about þe erle, & eke hys besechynge, the kynge name of hym manred fo&rtail; to hold leynestre of hym; & the Erl graunted þe kynge, dyuely&ntail;, & all the hauen tounes vpo&ntail; þe see, with ha&rtail; Candredes & castelles þer-vpo&ntail; y-set; & that othe&rtail; parte of hys conquestre, he & hys heyres sholde&ntail; holde&ntail; of þe kynge & hys heyrs.  Whan thys was al on thys manere I-done, the kynge toke the wey yn-to south Wales, & cam to pembroke; & the&rtail; yn þe contre abode with hys host longe whyle, a&rtail; he had wynd fo&rtail; to passe.  The whyle that he was tha&rtail;, he hadde houndes & haukes, as man that mych delyted yn suche game.  .O. day he went by the strond of þe see, & ba&rtail; a mych goshawke of northwey vpo&ntail; hys hand.  Than sat vp-o&ntail; an hegh clyff ouer the strond, a fauco&ntail; gentel, negh hys nest, the&rtail; he was woned to brede.  The goshake sawe the faco&ntail;, & a-bated to hym. the kynge that saw; & kest hym of hys hand; & he nam hys flyght toward the faco&ntail;, hym fore to henten: the faco&ntail; sawe hym comynge, & nam hys flyght an heghe, & escaped of hym; þe goshawke turned ayeyne to þe kynges hand; & a&rtail;
 he myght fully take to hym, the faco&ntail; smote to hym from an heyght, & forcleue hym the rygge, & kest hym adoune dede at the kynges foote.  Al thay that hyt saw, hadden the&rtail;-of myche wondyr. Than bade the kynge, that fro that tyme, the bryddes of that facons neste shold euer-mo&rtail; be I-kepte to hys owne be-houe; & so thay we&rtail;, euery yeyr; & yn al hys kynge-dome wer no&ntail; so good facons I-found, ne so bold.

22.1: The while that thys was, Roueryke, the kynge of Myth,—awayted that the erl was out of lond; & Reymond & lytel folk was beleft ar dyuelyn, the syte & þe contrey for to kepe,—with mych folke come to dyuely&ntail; about myd-heruest, & assaylled the walles of þe syte with gret streynth & loly crye, & wend wel to haue I-take þe syte, & al þat þer-In was.  bote ther streynthys & stalwarthnesse, hyt mote nedes shewe hymself: Myles de Coga&ntail; & hys me&ntail; preuely wenten out, & smote grymly vpon ham, so þat yn lytell whyl thay were&ntail; al dyscomfyted.  Bot roury hymself vnnethe escaped; & hys sone, a welle stalwarth man amonge hys folk, was tha&rtail; I-slawe, wyth many other.

23.1:
Later note in right margin: 'For in Martilogis the king brought 400 great shippes into Irelande, and in short time subdued the whole lande, beinge governed by 5 kinges, all which submitted to the king, except the king of Connaght, who kept himself in woods and marishes.' Afti&rtail; this, whan the kynge had I-dygℏt al that nede was to so noble comynge ynto Irlond, he went to seynth dauyes; & besoght the holy ma&ntail;, seynt dauy, with grett deuocion & mych wurshyppe.  And tho wede&rtail; hym come, & wynd at wylle. He put hym to saylle; passed the see, hool & sound; & arryued at Waterford on seynt lukes day, with fywe houndred knyghtes, & men, an hors an a foot, fulle many.  Than was fulfylled a prophycye that Merlyn seyd:  "out of þe Este shal come a fy&rtail; bernynge, & shal Irlond al about for-swely."  And seynt Molynge seyd þus: "Out of þe eeste shal come a stronge thondred, & shal smyte yn-to þe weste, & al the streynth of Ormond adoun brynge." He arryued, the ye&rtail; of hys kyngedome, senthe; of hys elde .xl.; 
 of ou&rtail; lordes Incarnacion .M.C.lxxij; & was poppe, Alexander the thryd; Emperou&rtail;, ffryderyke; kynge of ffraunce, lowyse.

24.1:
The kynge abode at Waterford a fewe dayes.  Thede&rtail; come the syt&yogh;eyns of weysford, & broght to hym Robert steuenesse-sone, as for gret seruyce, & yn hope of good reward; ffor as myche as he come yn-to Irlond, lond to conque&rtail;, wythout auctoryte of heghe&rtail; prynce, & yaue othe&rtail;, ensample for to comen ynto the lond.  The kynge, at the byggynnyge, told of hym grete vnworthynesse; & edwyte hym, with grete thretynge, of that grete boldnesse; & lete take hym, y-bound as he was, & gyued hym to anothe&rtail;, & put hym yn Rathnyldestou&rtail; for to kepe&ntail;.  Soine þer-afte&rtail; come the kynge of Corke, Dermot Maccarthy, & yeld hym to the kynge, & dydde hym homage, & swa&rtail; hym hold othes, & delyuered hym ostages for to be to hym hold & trew, & be&rtail; hym truage euery ye&rtail; of hys land.  ffrom thus, the kynge went wythe the hoste to lysmore, & the&rtail; was twey dayes; & fro thus, went to Casshle.  Thede&rtail; came donald Obree&ntail;, kynge of lymeryke, to hym vpo&ntail; the waty&rtail; of ssur; & for to hawe pees, yeld hym to þe kynge yn al manere as Maccathy hadde done. The kynge set kepers both at Corke & at lymeryke; & to hym comen the hoste of both contrees aftyr Maccathy & Obreen, & yeld ham to þe kynge, & becomen hys meyn by othes & ostages; so that the&rtail; was none that wa&rtail; of any name yn al Monestre, that by hys good wylle ne yeld hym to the kynge.  Whan thys was al I-done. the kynge, with mych wyrsshyppe & wyth ryche yiftes, lete euery ma&ntail; wend yn-to hys owne lond, & went hym-self by Tybrach ayeyne to Waterford. þer was ayeyne Robert y-broght to-for hym. The kynge saw hym, & bethoght hym of þe gret goodnesse þat was yn hym, & of hys stalwarthnesse & hys hardy hert; of many good seruices that he & hys hadden I-done, wyth mych trauaylle & grette perille of lyue: he had grett reuth of hym yn hys hert &, throgh besechynge of hegℏ men, al hys wreth, wyth good hert he hym foryaf, & delyueret hym out of pryso&ntail;, & lete delyuer hym hys londes þat hym were&ntail; be-nome&ntail;, of Weysford & of þe
 contrey about.  Some sygge&ntail; that the kynge lete to-draw the traytours that hym betrayed; Bot Maystre Geroud ne telleth nothynge þer-of; & the&rtail;-fore I ne tel hyt nat to sothe, bot hyt oght well be so.

25.1: Whan þe kynge had thus I-do, he left at Waterford, Robert beranardesso&ntail;, wyth mych meyne; &, by Ossery, name the wey toward dyuely&ntail;.  In that wyage, the kynge of Ossery came to hym, & yeld hym to the kynge; & whan he hade I-bydde awhylle at dyuely&ntail;, thede&rtail; come Al þe heghest Iresshe-me&ntail; of leynestre, & besoghten pees, & yolde&ntail; ham to the kyn>ail;.  Roryke O'conghou&rtail;, the kynge of Connaght, ayeyns the kynges messagers at the waty&rtail; shynnen,—that ys to wytte&ntail;, hugℏ þe lacy & wyllyam Al-delines sone,—the&rtail; he yeld hym to þe kynge; & the kynge of Myth Also; So that the&rtail; nas none hegℏt ma&ntail; yn Irland, that ne come to the kynges owne body, or sent messagers for to be-come&ntail; hys man, & yeld hym to hym, sawe only thay of vlnestre.  Than was fulfylled a prophecye that seynth Molynge seyd: "To-fo&rtail; hym shall foot- falle þe prynces, & trogℏ A later overline h is above the tr of 'trogh.' boxom-fastines or 'fastmes.' the lyme of pees shul vnderfonge."  Merlyn seyd an-other: "Tho is lyght, the foules of the Iland shollen togedder fle; & the most of ham, with har wenges I-brant, shollen ouerthrowen yn thraldome; the fyf deles shollen be broght yn-to on, & the syxt shal ouercome the strengest places of Irland."  Whan the mydwyntter came, many of the heghest comen to þe kynges court to feste; & myche wonder ham thoght of the noble seruice that þey þer saw, & of the myohe plente of mete & of drynke, of bordes I-sette, & fay&rtail; clothes vpon; the hegh seruice of panetrye & buttellerie, & ryche vessels of gold & sylue&rtail;; the many manere metes of kechen, on the manere of Englond, whych thay had neuer þer-to-fore I-sey.  After that þe fest was heghly & fay&rtail; I-hold, euery man went wyth gladnesse yn-to hys owne.  In that tyme, were&ntail; boweme&ntail; at ffynglas I-horberowed, & wenten ynto chyrche haye, & hewe&ntail; adoun trees, that seyntes by old tyme hadden þer I-sete: þer came sodey&ntail; deth vpon ham, euerycho&ntail;. [See Giraldus's Topogr. Hibern . Opera, v. 135.]

26.1: The lond was than yn good pees by-fo&rtail; þe kynge, & þe pees wel I-hold: the kynge had wel y-hard that þe folk of the lond was of vnclene lyf, & ayeyne god & holy chyrche; he thoght that he wold brynge the folk ynto bette&rtail; lyf, & myche desy&rtail; hadde the&rtail;-to; he leth assembly al þe clergye of þe londe at Casshell, & that me enquered & herd openly the fylthede of the lond-folk yn whych thay ladde ha&rtail; lyf; & setten hyt y&ntail; wrytte, vnde&rtail; the bysshoppes sele of lysmore, that was eke legat of þe court of Rome, & heghest of dygnyte ouer al thay that the&rtail; we&rtail;; & þe statutes of holy chyrche Whych yit me&ntail; halte, yn þe manere þat holy chyrche ham holte yn Englond, he lete tha&rtail; sette: whych statut&yogh;, yn the wordes that thay were&ntail; the&rtail; I-swewed, ys non harme thegℏ me expresse ham here:—

27.1:
In the yer of ou&rtail; lordes Incarnacio&ntail; M.C.lxxij, the forme ye&rtail; that þe kynge of england, henry, Irland wan; Crystye&ntail;, bysshoppe of lysmore, & legat of þe court of Rome Late sidenote in MS.: 'Establishment of orders for the Clergy, and matters of Religion.' ; Doughe&rtail;, Erchebysshoppe of Casshell; lauren&yogh;, Erchebysshoppe of dyuely&ntail;; Cathel, erchebysshoppe of Connaght; wyth leed byssho&pmacr;&pmacr;es, Abbotes, priours, & many other prelates of holy chyrche yn Irland, throgh the same kynges commaundement come&ntail; to-gedde&rtail; yn þe See of Casshel; &, for þe state of holy chyrch to brynge yn-to bette&rtail; fourme, helden the&rtail; ha&rtail; conssaylle. To thys conseyl, come&ntail; these from the kynge I-sent: a noble man Rolf, abbot of byldewdys; Ralf, Erchedekene of landaf; Nychol the prest, & othe&rtail; many, the kynges clerkes & hys messagers. The statutes o&rtail; constytucions of that consaylle be&ntail; these here I-wrytten, & by the kynges auctoryte I-stablet.  ¶ The fyrst ys, that crysten men In Irland shvllen leue&ntail; ha&rtail; kynnes-wommen & he&rtail; sybbes, whyche þay have a&rtail; thys I-hold to ha&rtail; wylle out of spoushode, & lawfully spouse othe&rtail; wommen, & spousehede lawfully hold repudiato cognatarum et affinium contubernio, legitima contrahant matrimonia, et observent .— Op . v. 282. .  That othe&rtail; ys, that the chyldre&ntail;, at þe chyrche dorre shulle&ntail; be&ntail; I-primseined catezizentur . of the prestes hond, & yn þe holy fantstones yn ha&rtail; moder chyrches to be I-fulled baptizentur . .  The thrydde, 
 that euery crysten man lawfullych pay hys tethynges to hys paroche chyrche, of corne & of al othe&rtail; thynge that a ye&rtail; hym aneweth 16th century side-note: 'the privileges and frydom gyven to the church, and londs ther of.' .  ¶ The ferthe, that al þe londes of holy chyrche & ha&rtail; possessiouns, of al herthly askynge be quyte; & namely, that no kynges ne other heye men, ne he&rtail; sonnes, ne he&rtail; meygnees, mette ne herbrowe yn chyrche londes, ne ask, ne wyth streynth ne be so hardy to take; & that Cursed me te that four syth a ye&rtail; was wonet to be asked y&ntail; chyrche tounes, & of the next neghbors, neuer eft be asked.  ¶ The fyft, that of manslaghttre that lewed men doth, whan man maketh fy&ntail; with hys foma&ntail;, the clerkes that ben hys kynnes-me&ntail;, no þynge ne yeue ne yeld ther-to; bot, as thay be&ntail; gyltles of the dede, also be thay harmles of þe payement.  ¶ The syxth, that wha&ntail; a man ys seke, he shal make testament openly to-fo&rtail; hys prestes of the parorcℏ, & to-fore hys neghbors; & after hys dettes & seruauntes hyre out take, dele hys catel a thre; yf he hath wyf & chyldre&ntail;, that on to hys spoused wyf, that other to hys shyldre&ntail;, The thryde to hys testament.  And yf he hath non chyldren by spouse, the good be y-deled bytwene hym & hys wyf, euery Ilyche; & yf the wyf deyeth, the goodes be I-deleth a thre bytwene the housbond, & the chyldren, & the wyf.  ¶ The .vij. that wha&ntail; a man othe&rtail; a woman deyeth, ha&rtail; wathe ? mistake for 'wache,' or th used for k, as on p. 67, 1. 4. , & the seruyce of holy chyrche, & the buryeng, be man-shyply I-done. ¶ The .viij. that al me&ntail; & wommen wyrshyppe holy chyrche, & oft go to chyrche; & holy chyrche y&ntail; al seruyce be gouerned on the maner that hyt ys yn England.  In al these thynges, the kynge ynto the lond come, many defautes we&rtail; yn the land I-found, & mych horynesse or oryble synnes that me ne aght nat to speke of, that—throgh grace of god, & by the kynges purueyaunce & hys myght—weren amendet, & yn bette&rtail; wonne I-bro&yogh;th.  ¶ The prymat of Ardmagh was nat at thys conssaylle, ne thede&rtail; myght come, for he wase old Man & feble; Bot he come the&rtail;-after to dyuely&ntail;, & graunted yn al thyn>ail; the kynges purueyaunce.  In thys tyme was the wede&rtail; so stronge, & the wynd so aweyward, that yn al the wyntyr ne myght no shyppe com ouer yn-to Irland. 
 The kynge went to Watyrford, & abode the&rtail; a whyle, & ful mych desyre adde for to hyr tythynges from beyont see.  & of the knyghtes that he fond yn Irland, he drogℏ to hym sleghly for o coste the beste: as Reymond, Myles de Cogan, wyllyam Masturel, & other, for to make hys part þe strenge&rtail;, & the Erles parte the fobler so .  ¶ After the myd-lente, come shyppes yn-to Irland, that hard tythynges hym broght, & lydder, bothe out of engeland & out of fraunce, And normande, & other londes; ffor ynto Normandy weren ycome twey cardinalles, from the poppe Alexander y-sent (that oon heght Albertus, & that other Theodynus), for to serchen & enqueren of the holy martyres deth, seynt Thomas: ryghtful men, as me vnderstond, & to that lawfully y-chosen / natheles thay weren Romayns; & such folweth oft coueytyse; &, bot the kynge come the rather to ham, the kyngedome of england, & al the londes that he was lord of, sholden be entredyted.  & (as me fynd oft , good aduentures comen oft slowly & aloon, bot mesaduentures ne cometh neuer-more aloon;) wyth thay tythynges comen othe&rtail; mychel wers, & of more perylle; ffor the kynges sone, henry, the eldest, whyche he so fayne was obout to crowne kynge of England, & other tweyn of hys bretheren, (that throgh yought & foolrede hym folwed, & many drogℏ to ham, both of england & of beyend þe see,) waren I-swore to-gredde&rtail; to entre vp-on the kynge, & bynyn hys londes, The whyle that he was yn Irland: & wel may be that hyt was I-purueyed bytwen ham, ar he ynto Irland wente.
27.2: ¶ Whan the kynge thys herd, he was yn grete anguysshe. sory he was at the begynnyge, þat he, gyltles, was I-retted of the holy mannes deth; sore he was afred that hys londes shold bene I-shent throght that lydder dede of hys sonne; sore hym forthoght, that he the lond of Irland so sone most fore-lete, whyche he hade y-cast for to streynth with castell, & stable yn pees, the next somer that was to comen.  Of al thys, he was yn many thoghtes; & spake the&rtail;-of fyrst to hymself, þer-after to hys men. Afty&rtail; many redes, he sent some of hys ynto England by-fore hym; & the&rtail;-after he puruyed how he myght sykyrlychest kepe Irland.

28.1:
He left at dyuelyn, the cyte & the contray to kepe, hught de lassy, wyth .xx.ti knyghtes; Robert steuenes-sone, & Moryce fytz Geraud, wytht other .xx. ti at Waterford; hunfrey de boun, Robert Bernardesso&ntail;, & hugh de Gundeuyl wyth .xl. ti knyghtes; At weysford, wyllyam Al-delines-sone Weisefordiae, vero Guillelmo Aldelini filio, Philippo de Hastinges, et Philippo de Breusa .— Op . v. 286. [William Fitz-Audeline.] & phylppe de Breuse wyth .xx. ti knyghtes.  And a morow after Estre day herly, he dydde hym to saylle at Weysford, & arryued at seynth dauyes, sone after none.  Whan he come a lond, he went wyth grete deuoccion to the mody&rtail; chyrche, as a pylgrymage, a-foot, with a burdo&ntail; yn hys hond.  Come the chanons of the chyrche ayeyne hym at the whyte yate, & with fayr processioun, with mych reuerence, & with mych manshype, hym receyued.  As þe processyoun yede a rewe to-for hym, come a walche womman, & fel hym to þe feet, & made a myche mone, yn hyre langage, of the bysshope of that place.  The kynge stode, & herd hyr mone || of an ynterpretour-es mouth that hyt hym told; & fo&rtail; he went forth, & dydde hyr no ryght anoon as tho wolde, she smote hy&rtail; handes to-gyddre, & bytterly began to crye tofore ham Al, a walshe langage, "A-wreke vs to-daye, lahlauar!  A-wreke ou&rtail; kynred & ou&rtail; folke of thys man!"  Thay that vnderstode hyr speche, put hyr away, & fore-bade hyre cryynge; & sho so myche the more cryed yn the same manere, & hoped to an old prophecye that Merlyn seyd: "The kynge of england that shal wyn Irland shal be I-woundet yn Irland of a man with a rede hond; & as he cometh ayeyne by south wales, he shal deye vpon lehlaua&rtail;:" Þat was þe name of a stone, that lay ouer a streme by north the chyrche heye of seynt dauyes, yn stydde of a brygge.  The stone was of Marbel wel fay&rtail;, & smothe of mannes geynge, & hadde .x. feet yn leynth, & .vi. yn brede, & a foot thykke.  And ys 'lehlaua&rtail;,' a walshe, as mych to sygge as 'a spekynge stone.'  And hyt was ytold, that som tyme as me ba&rtail; a dede body ouer that stone, he bega&ntail; to speke; & wyth the spech he claue throgℏout; & yit the clyft ys I-sene, & yit yn-to thys day me be-bereth no dydde body ouer that stone.  The kynge come to that stone, & bethoght 
 hym of that prophecye.  & he stode at þe stones end & grymly hyt be-hold; & awhyle ther-after, boldely yede ouer a good paas.  & whan he was ouer, he turned ayeyne to þe stone, & deynously þus seyd: "Who shal heten-forward beleue Merlyn the leye&rtail;?"  A man stode þer besyde & herd, & wold, hys thankes, saue þe prophetes sawe, Answard the kynge & seyd, "Thou art nat that kynge that shal Irland conquer; ne Merlyn ne speketh nat of the."  Thus the kynge went yn-to the chyrch, yn seynt Andrees & seynt dauyes wyrshyppe I-sette, & herd hys masse of a preste that was I-found fastynge, as god wold.  After masse, he eete hys mete ther, & after mete wente to hauerford, than ouer .xl. myle; ffrom thens he wente hastyly yn-to englande; out of enland yn-to Normandy, & come to-for þe cardynalls with mych buxumnesse at Custance.  Ther, after myche dalyaunce & many wordes I-spoke, he excused hym by othes of þe holye Martyres deth, that he was nat by hym I-slaw; bot he ne for-sok nat that he nas for hym; & þerfor he vndretoke such penaunce as holy chyrche hym wold loke.  Þe cardynals, he sent ayeyne wyth myche wyrshyppe; & noon he went to þe marche, & ther he spake with the kynge of ffraunce.  þer, (throgh besechynge of hegℏ men, & namely of phylepe þe erl of flaundres, that from seynt James was ryght than I-come,) the pees was made betwene the twey kynges, of the wreth that was betwene ham fo&rtail; the forseyd martyres deth; ffor-thy that þe kynge of ffraunce, with othe&rtail; mychel & myghty men, name an hand to the erchebysshopp whan he shold turne ayeyne yn-to England, ayeyn the pees betwen the kynge & hym.  ffor þer was pees thus y-made betwene the kynges, al the harme þat the sones with ha&rtail; allyees hadden throght to do, was I-lost tyl þe next yere the&rtail;aftyr.

29.1:
Wnder this, as the lond of Irland was yn good pees vnder ham that weren In lefte, the lond for to kepe, byfelle that a day of parlement, at a certeyne place, was betaken by-twene hugℏ de lacy, whom the kynge had I-yeue dyuelyn to kepe with trust, And þe kynge of Myth.  a nythe, whan the parlement shold ben a morow, a knygh t that was Moryce fytz Geraudes neuew, & Robert Gryffyn by name, thoght yn hys
 slepe that he saw a mych flote of wylde swyne yernynge vp-on hugh & moryce; & a boore amonge ham, myche & grysly ouer al othe&rtail;, come toward ham, & with hys tuskes wold haue smytten ha&mtail; & I-slawe, yf he stalwarthly ne had y-come betwene, & I-slawe the bore, & I-holpe ham bothe.  A morow, thay went to þe place ther þe parlement was I-sette, at a place that me hath seth y-cleped 'rorykes hylle': ffyrst thay helden har parlement from fer&rtail;, by messagers goynge betwe&ntail;; the&rtail;-after thay name sekernesse of othes I-sworne, & comen to-geddre by forward; natheles few, & ylych fale on ethe&rtail; halue, and thay vnwepened,—bot the one, her swerdes; & the othe&rtail;, he&rtail; sparthes,—& ether of har folke somdel fer from ham.  Gryffyn, that with Moryce was to the parlement I-come, was ful thought-ful of the vysyo&ntail; that he sawe. he name to hym seuy&ntail; knyghtes of hys owne kyn, than that ho moost truste to har stalwardnesse, & drowen ham on the on halfe of the hylle, as neyght as thay myght leppen vpon har stedes, with sheldes about ha&rtail; nekkes, & speres an-hond; & for a coste, pleneden & prykkeden har hors ayey&ntail; other, so that, yn whych halue the parlement turned, throght encheson of such pley thay myght be fonden Redy.  Roryk & hugh helden ha&rtail; parlement of many thynge; bot of nothynge thay myght nat accord, & begyn to departe a wrethe.  The traytour Roryk had yn hys thoght þe trayso&ntail; þat he hadde I-purueyed. he made semblant, & draw hym by-halues as for to pyssen, & made tokens to hys men that thay hastely shold come to hym.  Whan he thys hadde I-done, he turned ayeyne wyth hys sparth an hegh, hys wysage al blak with ful snel goynge.  Moryce was Iwarned of hys neueu, of the vysyo&ntail; that he sawe; stod, & beheld al thys.  he hent out þe swerd, & cryed vpon hugh, & mynyed hym, & dyd hym-self ayeyne the traytour, for to defend hym.  The traytour ran to hugh, hym for to smyte; har latymer yed betwene hym & the dynt; & he smote hym of the oon arme, fast by the sholdre.  Moryce stode, & campled wyth hys swerd ayeyne the sparthe, & lowd cryed to har men.  & ar hugh myght be yn any state, hym-self fo&rtail; to helpe, throgh grete hastynge, he felle twys abak; & vnnethe, throgh helpe of Moryce, that hym defendet thus, Hugh escaped wyth hys
 lyf.  The whyll that thys was, Rorykes men ful many come to hys clepynge, out of dales & wodes about, yernynge to ham wyth speres & with sparthes, for to brynge hugh & Moryce out of dawes.  Than Gryffyn & hys felewes come&ntail; yernynge vp on har hors styffly to ham.  þe traytou&rtail; saw ham comynge, & lep to hors that to hym was broght, & wold do hym to flyght; & as he lepe, vp come Gryffy&ntail;, & wyth hys spere smote hym & hys hors throghout, & slowe hem bothe.  Wyth hym we&rtail; I-slayne þay that, yn so mych perylle, the hors hym broght; & hy s heed I-smytten of, & yn-to england þer-after to the kynge I-sent; & al hys men yn-to al the feldes dyscomfyte, & I-slawe ful many.  Rolf, Robertes sone fytz Stephen, was the othe&rtail; stalwardthest that daye yn the felde The twelve lines on the back of fol. 15, 'a bak (p. 74, at foot) . . . felde,' were first written by mistake on fol. 16, but afterwards struck out. .

30.1: Morice was a mane ful wyrshypful & chamfaste; vysage wel colowred; becomlyche; lytel of body, sumdele more þan lytel, & lasse than metlych.  of hert, & body, wel I-thewed; nothynge hauteyne.  of k i ndly goodnes, he was good; & leuer hym was be good, tha&ntail; be sey good; hys maner was euer-more to hold hym methelyche.  man of short spech & lytel, bot of fay&rtail; wordes, as he that more hadde yn hert than yn mouth, more of wytte & reyso&ntail; þan of spech.  Nat forthy ? MS. Rat fortly. , whan tyme was, & nede to sp e ken, to good reyso&ntail; forth brynge,—as lettred as he was, as wytty he was "Nat forthy, whan tyme was, & nede to sp e ken, to good reyso&ntail; forth brynge,—as lettred as he was, as wytty he was" = Et tamen, cum sermonem res exigebat, ad sententiam dicendam sicut serus, sic scientissimus .— Op . v. 297. .  In thynge that byfell to bataylle, swyth hardy, & vnnethes of stalwarthnesse any was hys bettre; natheles, of perille to take, he was nat to hastyf ne to fool-hardy.  bot as he was thus, & of purueaunce thynge to begynne, Also he was stronge & stydfast yn thynge Wha&ntail; he hyt hadde begune.  he was sobre, wel I-thewed & chaste, lawful, & stydfast, without blame.

31.1:
In the next auril the&rtail;-after, þe yonge&rtail; kynge henry, þe kynges sone, the lyddernysse that he hadde I-thoght to hys 
 fadyr nold no lenger hellen; with hys twey brethere&ntail;—that ys to wytte, the Erl of peytou & the erl of brytay&ntail; Pictaviae scilicet et Britanniae comitibus .— Op . v. 297-8. —wenten to the kynge of ffraunce, whose doghte&rtail; he hadde I-spoused, & purchased helpe of hym for to wer&rtail; vpon hys fady&rtail;.  The encheso&ntail; whe&rtail;-fo&rtail; hyt was, Mayster Geraud ne telleth nat, ne I ne ca&ntail; nat sey; bot many hegℏ & Ryche men he hadde to consaylle & to helpe, both of England & of beyend the see; many openly & wel; most, illy & dernely.  The old kynge, the yonge&rtail; kynges fady&rtail;, fo&rtail; the fortune that hym come to o&ntail; euery halue so vnwarly, was ful sorowful. ¶ Nathales, throgh gret sleght & hegℏ herth, he made fay&rtail; semblant, & heped to god; & o&ntail; euery syde that he myght, yn al maner he besoght help.  He sent messagers ynto Irland, & mad come ouer to hym the meste parte of the knyghtes & of the good meygne þat he ther hadde I-lefte.  Thay come to hym at the cyte of Ruem, & he bethogh hym that hyt was perylle to leue har lond vnkepet; ther he betoke þe Erl Rychard al þe lond to kepe, & sette to hym Reymond as hys othe&rtail; hand; ffor the erl for-soke al out & out, þat he that kepynge wold nat receyue, bot yf he hadde Reymond with hym for to helpe.

32.1:
The Erle & Reymond, with ha&rtail; powe&rtail;, wentten yn-to Irland; &, for the folk of yrland hade y-hard of the mych stryff that was betwene the kynge & hys sonnys be-yent the see,—as folk þat styddefast ys yn vnstedfastnesse, & lawfully ham holt to vnlawfulnesse,—the most parte of the prynces of þe lond, ayeyn har trouth I-found, þay turned ayeyn-to the kynge.  The erl hadde sone I-spend the traysou&rtail; that he broght ouer wyth hym; & whan the meygne lacked spendynge, & nat spedden yn prayes takynge vnde&rtail; heruy, that was conestable ouer the meygne, & euer hadde enuy to Reymond, Thay wente&ntail; ham to the erl comynly by one accorde, & sey hym wel, that 'bot yf he wold sete Reymond ouer ham, thay wold leue hym euerychone, & wend yn-to england; oþer, that wel wors was, thay wold turnet to ha&rtail; enemyes ayeyns har heed.'  As the meygne wold, Reymond was I-sette ouer ham; thay name than hert to ham, & wenten vpon the Ofolanes yn the dees, 
 & name grett prayes, arrayed ham nobly wyth hors & wepne. From thens thay wentte&ntail; to lysmore, & the cyte, & al þe contre about, robbeden & prayeden, & by the see wey senten many grete prayes to Watyrford; & of pylfre & thynge that thay namen, thay fylled .xiij. far costes that were&ntail; I-come fro Waterford yn-to the hauen of dongaruame.  As thay we&rtail; wynd abydynge, the&rtail; come þe men of Cork from by west, by the see, yn xxxij shyppys, & many men the&rtail;-In, for to take thay other.  The&rtail; was the fyght styffely I-yeuen, of these twey fletes yn the see: That oon assaylled that other grymlych with stones & with sparthes; the othe&rtail; were&ntail; welle I-wepned, & with-stode styffly with arblastes & with bowes. At þe end, thay of Corke weren descomfyted & ouer-come; he&rtail; shyppys I-take; he&rtail; men I-slawe, & I-caste yn the see.  Adam de herford & phylep de Wellsse, that weren I-sette ouer thay yonglynges, with mo shyppes & grete beyetes of wepne & of pylfre, to Watyrford wenten with grete yoye.  Reymond herd speke of thys fyght, & tythynges to hym come; he toke with hym xx ti knyghtes & an hundreth bowmen, & went by the see wey thederward. Than come to hym tythynges þat dermot, þe prynce of desmond, was, with myche hostes, come&ntail; to lysmore, to helpe ham of Cork. Reymond went hym thederward.  Þe prynce that herd, & turned tyeyne, & durst hym nat abyde.  And Reymond went forthe&rtail; yn-to the contrey, robbed & prayed, so that he hadde with hym at hys turny n ge aye toward Watyrford, four thousand kyne; & as thay wer comynge by narow weyes wyth har praye, come the Ireshemen of þe contray, & henten a party of har kyne, & wenten al quytten with ham to wodde.  þe crye arose, & Reymond The Latin text gives this exploit to Meiler: Gir. Cambr. Op . v. 309-10, ' et in primis Meilerius, ut erat praeceps semper et probus, satellite quodam comitatus equestri, praedones usque ad silvae condensa est persecutus .' (as man that euer was formost redy) went aftyr, with o&ntail; priuisant man an hors wyth hym; come to the woddes ense Ends. , the&rtail; the theues weren an hydynge.  Whan he hadde I-faylled of þe preye, & wolde turne ayeyne, hys felewes folyly entyced hym for to wende yn-to þe wodde, & he so dydde.  Whan thay weren wel with-yn, 
 the Irysshe-men rysse to ham on euery halue, & leyd ham o&ntail;, & anoo&ntail;-ryght the yonge ma&ntail; was al to-hakked to-for hym; he yarne to snellych for to socu&rtail; hym, & was assaylled o&ntail; euery halue; & he, as man, hent out the swerd & leyd on about hym, & smot of that ma&ntail; the hond, þat othe&rtail; the arme, þe þryd the heede by þe sholdres; thus he opened hym the wey, & come out to hys men, & brogℏt twey sparthes fast on hys sheld, & thre on hys hors tres secures Hibernicas in equo confixas, duasque in clipeo portans .—Gir. Camb. Op . v. 310. ; bot all hool & sound, & harmeles of body, he escaped.

33.1:
Whan thys was y-done, & the meygne was noblych arrayed both byl ond & eke by waty&rtail;, come tythynges to Reymond, that hys fady&rtail; Wyllyam fytz Geraud was dede. Reymond went ouere yn-to Walys, to take seysyne yn hys fady&rtail; landys; & heruy was the whyle eft y-made conestable of þe meygne: he wold fayne entremette hym to do some thynge the whyle that Reymond was out of londe, & made the Erl & the meyne wend to Casse&llbar; for to weren yn Monestre; he sent eke after the meyne of dyuelyn to come to ham.
